Description: Wheel-made pottery oil-lamp with a flattened globular body and an inward-sloping rim, and long, tapering flat-topped nozzle. Covered with a metalilc black glaze. Fine orange fabric.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from Athens (Howland 1958, Type 25A, dated 375BC-275BC) . Late 4th or 3rd century BC parallel from Alexandria (Blondé 1998, 313-4, no. 1). Blondé, F. 1998. Lampes tournée Hellénistiques du Musée d’Alexandrie, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 307-35. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.40) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4837 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
